title: Telescope: The New AIDS Epidemic: Tell us what you know about HIV and AIDS
text: What ever happened to AIDS? That’s the question we’ll be exploring over the next 10 months in POLITICO’s Telescope: The New AIDS Epidemic. Thirty-five years after the discovery of HIV — and the explosion of an epidemic that transformed the world — AIDS rarely makes the headlines. It once revolutionized the way we approach outbreaks of disease, upended the economics of the pharmaceutical industry and changed some of the most intimate aspects of how we live our lives, devastating entire communities as it did so. Today, breakthroughs in treatment have transformed it from a death sentence into a manageable disease and progress in prevention has largely pushed it out of the public consciousness in wealthy countries. The truth, however, is that HIV still lurks beneath the surface, where it continues to transform communities across the world. That’s why we’re making HIV and AIDS the subject of POLITICO’s first-ever Telescope — our marquee home for in-depth reporting and analysis on the biggest challenges facing politicians, policymakers and business leaders. Over the next 10 months, we’ll be holding the mirror up to the modern face of AIDS, looking at how the challenges have mutated and metastasized since the early years of the epidemic. From San Francisco to Johannesburg, from Paris to Kiev, we’ll be looking at how policymakers, medical workers and regular people responding to HIV and AIDS today. Do you have insights about HIV or AIDS you want to share? Send me a note. Just let me know if you’d prefer to stay anonymous: telescope@politico.eu We’ll be back with some of your answers in our next monthly POLITICO Telescope newsletter.
